docs.title: Home
docs.text:
Hybrid Rocket Groundstation

Ops-first, safety-forward documentation

Everything needed to build, operate, and review the groundstation: architecture, procedures, safety intent, and verification.

Operators Engineers Reviewers

docs.title: How to use this site
docs.text:
• Operators: go to operation/ for checklists and to physical-ui/ for button/indicator mappings.
  • Engineers: hardware/, software/, and development/ capture architecture, build steps, and change control.
  • Reviewers: safety/ sets intent; testing/ and appendix/ carry evidence and traceability.

docs.title: System snapshot
docs.text:
• Purpose: provide a reliable ground interface for hybrid rocket operations (telemetry, command, abort).
  • Platform: single-board computer with hardened I/O, physical UI, and network links to the vehicle and local LAN.
  • Safety posture: default-to-safe, human-in-the-loop, with physical dead-man and software interlocks.

docs.title: Navigation hints
docs.text:
• Start with overview/mission-context.md for mission framing.
  • Keep diagrams current in diagrams/; text should reference them directly.
  • Track changes in appendix/revision-history.md so reviewers can see deltas per release.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text:
Common terms and abbreviations used across the documentation.

Term Definition

Keep this synchronized with overview/terminology.md.

docs.title: Licenses
docs.text:
State licenses for documentation, code snippets, and third-party assets.

  • Repository license.
  • Attribution for diagrams or borrowed templates.
  • Third-party fonts/icons if used in the dashboard.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
List standards, datasheets, and external documents referenced elsewhere.

  • EuRoC rule references.
  • Hardware datasheets (compute board, regulators, radios).
  • Safety standards followed.
  • Links to test reports or external logs.

docs.title: Revision History
docs.text:
Track changes to the documentation and the groundstation configuration.

Version Date Author Summary v0.1 Initial baseline skeleton

Add entries for each meaningful change; link to related commits when possible.

docs.title: Build Instructions
docs.text:
How to build and preview the documentation locally.

pip install -r requirements.txt
mkdocs serve
  • Note Python version expectations.
  • Call out any optional plugins or extensions.
  • Describe how to build static output (mkdocs build) and where it lands.

docs.title: CI/CD
docs.text:
Document automation for docs publishing.

  • GitHub Actions workflow summary (see .github/workflows/deploy.yml).
  • Branch triggers and environments.
  • Secrets required (if any) and how they are stored.
  • How to validate changes before merge.

docs.title: Coding Standards
docs.text:
Standards for scripts and configuration that accompany the docs.

  • Preferred languages/tools (Python, shell) and formatting rules.
  • Linting/testing expectations before committing.
  • How to document scripts and keep example commands reproducible.
  • Versioning policy for docs (tags/releases).

docs.title: Local Development
docs.text:
Guidance for contributors.

  • Writing style (succinct, operator-first, safety-forward).
  • How to add pages and update navigation.
  • Diagram standards (prefer Mermaid or vector exports).
  • How to cross-link sections and keep references stable.

docs.title: Repository Structure
docs.text:
Describe how the documentation and supporting assets are organized.

  • MkDocs layout (mkdocs.yml, docs/, diagrams/ assets).
  • Location for generated artifacts (if any) and what should be committed.
  • Naming conventions for files and diagrams.
  • Branching strategy for docs changes.

docs.title: Network Topology
docs.text:
Diagram the network paths and addressing.

flowchart LR
  LAN[(Ops LAN)] --> Switch
  Switch --> GS[Groundstation]
  GS --> PadLink[Pad Link/Radio]
  PadLink --> Vehicle

Include VLANs, IP ranges, and link characteristics.

docs.title: Power Flow
docs.text:
Document how power enters, is regulated, and is distributed.

flowchart LR
  Source[Input Source] --> PD[Power Distribution]
  PD --> Reg12[12V Reg]
  PD --> Reg5[5V Reg]
  Reg12 --> Relays
  Reg5 --> Compute
  PD --> Aux[Aux Outputs]

Include current limits, fuse ratings, and protection notes alongside the diagram.

docs.title: Safety State Machine
docs.text:
Capture the safety/arming states and transitions.

stateDiagram-v2
  [*] --> Standby
  Standby --> Armed : checklist complete\nDMS held
  Armed --> Abort : fault detected\noperator abort
  Armed --> Active : command issued
  Active --> Abort : fault detected
  Abort --> Standby : reset and verify

Align this with safety/interlocks.md and operational checklists.

docs.title: System Block Diagram
docs.text:
Maintain an up-to-date high-level block diagram of the groundstation.

flowchart LR
  Operator -->|buttons| PhysicalUI
  PhysicalUI --> SafetyLogic
  SafetyLogic --> Compute
  Compute -->|telemetry| Dashboard
  Compute -->|commands| Vehicle
  Compute --> DataLog

Replace with the authoritative diagram used in design reviews.

docs.title: Hardware Architecture
docs.text:
High-level physical architecture of the groundstation.

  • Core compute, I/O cards, and safety hardware.
  • External interfaces (vehicle umbilical, sensors, pad control, LAN).
  • Segmentation rationale (what is isolated and why).
  • Include or link a block diagram (diagrams/system-block-diagram.md).

State design assumptions and constraints (power input range, enclosure rating, environmental limits).

docs.text:

Include alternates for long-lead parts and note any calibration requirements.

docs.title: Compute
docs.text:
Document the main compute platform.

  • Board make/model, CPU, memory, storage, expansion.
  • Operating modes (normal, maintenance).
  • Peripherals (USB, GPIO, serial, CAN, network ports).
  • Cooling, mounting, and physical access guidance.
  • Recovery path (boot device, console access).

docs.title: Interfaces
docs.text:
Physical and electrical interfaces to external systems.

  • Connectors, pinouts, and signaling levels.
  • Controlled outputs (valves, igniters, pumps) with maximum ratings.
  • Sensor/telemetry inputs and expected ranges.
  • Safety interlocks on each path (e.g., relay enable, fuse, current limit).

Use tables for pin maps and reference detailed wiring in wiring.md.

docs.title: Networking
docs.text:
Detail network topology and interfaces.

  • Interfaces (Ethernet ports, Wi-Fi, radio link) and their roles.
  • Addressing scheme, VLANs, and segregation between ops LAN and vehicle link.
  • Bandwidth/latency expectations and QoS rules.
  • Clock/timing sync approach if applicable.
  • Cable/connectors and environmental hardening.

Keep the live topology diagram in diagrams/network-topology.md.

docs.title: Power System
docs.text:
Describe power sources, regulation, and monitoring.

  • Input sources (battery, AC mains PSU) and selection strategy.
  • Regulation chain with nominal/current limits and protections.
  • Power domains and what each feeds (compute, relays, UI, radios).
  • Power quality monitoring and thresholds for alarms/shutdown.
  • Procedures for brown-out or over-voltage conditions.

Include a power-flow diagram in diagrams/power-flow.md.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
Wiring and harness documentation for assembly and maintenance.

  • Cable types, gauges, shielding, and grounding strategy.
  • Routing guidance and separation of power vs. signal.
  • Labeling scheme and physical tags.
  • Photos or diagrams of critical harnesses.
  • Test points and continuity checks.

Include inspection checklists before close-out.

docs.title: Abort Procedures
docs.text:
How to safely abort operations.

  • Triggers for abort (automatic and manual).
  • Physical actions (DMS, buttons) and software actions.
  • Post-abort stabilization steps.
  • Communication and reporting during/after abort.
  • Reset path to return to standby.

docs.title: Maintenance
docs.text:
Scheduled and as-needed maintenance tasks.

  • Inspection intervals for connectors, wiring, fans/filters.
  • Firmware/software update cadence.
  • Calibration tasks and tools needed.
  • Spare parts and consumables inventory.
  • Recording maintenance actions in revision history.

docs.title: Normal Operation
docs.text:
Standard sequence for a nominal run.

  • Roles and callouts.
  • Power-up and initialization sequence.
  • Monitoring tasks and expected indicators.
  • Commanding steps (arming, pressurization, hold points).
  • Logging requirements.

Reference relevant diagrams and dashboards for clarity.

docs.title: Pre-Operation Checklist
docs.text:
Actions to complete before powering or connecting the groundstation to the vehicle.

  • Hardware inspection (enclosure closed, connectors secure, wiring tags present).
  • Power checks (input source, voltage range, DMS test).
  • Network checks (link status, addressing).
  • Software state (services running, configs correct, time sync).
  • Communication check with vehicle/pad.

Keep this in a printable, step-by-step format.

docs.title: Shutdown
docs.text:
Orderly shutdown to protect hardware and data.

  • Command sequence to safe states.
  • Power-down order and delays.
  • Data/log collection and backups.
  • Post-run inspections and notes.

docs.title: Mission Context
docs.text:
Describe the operational environment and mission the groundstation supports.

  • Mission objectives and constraints (launch site, range safety, schedule).
  • Interfaces to vehicle, pad systems, and ops center.
  • Expected environmental factors (temperature, dust, RF noise).
  • Stakeholders and roles during operations.

Keep this concise and link to deeper technical detail in other sections.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
Capture top-level requirements with clear IDs to trace through design, tests, and operations.

ID Requirement Rationale Verification REQ-GS-001 REQ-GS-002

Guidance: - Keep requirements testable and unambiguous. - Tag related risks or hazards and reference mitigation pages in safety/. - Note requirement status (draft, baseline, retired) as revisions progress.

docs.title: System Goals
docs.text:
Document what success looks like for the groundstation.

  • Functional goals (e.g., maintain telemetry link, issue arming/abort, log data).
  • Performance targets (latency, uptime, power budget, network bandwidth).
  • Human factors goals (single-person operation? two-person verification?).
  • Safety goals (fail-safe behaviors, physical overrides).
  • Verification goals (what tests prove each requirement is met).

docs.title: Terminology
docs.text:
Define the terms, abbreviations, and signals used in the groundstation to keep language consistent across teams.

  • Groundstation, GS:
  • Vehicle:
  • Arming vs. firing vs. abort:
  • DMS: Dead-man switch behavior and timing.
  • Network segments (LAN, pad link, telemetry backhaul):

Link to appendix/glossary.md for an expanded list and to hardware/interfaces.md for pin/connector names.

docs.title: Button Panel
docs.text:
Map each button/switch to its function and safeguards.

  • Layout diagram or photo reference.
  • Actions triggered, debounce/filtering strategy, and required confirmations.
  • Interaction with software interlocks and permissions.
  • Failure modes (stuck button, switch mismatch) and detection.

Provide a quick reference table operators can print and tape to the panel.

docs.title: Dead-Man Switch
docs.text:
Detail the dead-man switch (DMS) behavior and rationale.

  • Electrical implementation and monitored signals.
  • Timing parameters (hold duration, timeout to safe state).
  • What systems it enables/holds safe.
  • Test procedure before each operation.
  • Behavior under power loss or network loss.

This is a key safety element—cross-reference safety/interlocks.md.

docs.title: Enclosure
docs.text:
Describe the physical enclosure and environmental protections.

  • Dimensions, ingress protection, and mounting.
  • Cable ingress/egress, strain relief, and EMI shielding.
  • Thermal management and airflow paths.
  • Serviceability: how to open safely, tool list, and torque specs if any.

docs.title: Indicators
docs.text:
Document LEDs, displays, buzzers, and their meanings.

  • Indicator mapping (color/state → meaning).
  • Priority levels and escalation rules (flash patterns, audible alarms).
  • Dependency on telemetry (e.g., loss of link → flashing amber).
  • Night/low-light considerations.

Add alarm acknowledgement steps if applicable.

docs.title: Physical UI Overview
docs.text:
Describe the operator-facing controls and indicators and why they exist.

  • Philosophy: physical controls for safety, clarity, and speed.
  • Roles: who is authorized to press what and under which procedure.
  • Summary of panels: buttons, switches, dead-man, indicators, buzzer.
  • Accessibility and ergonomics considerations.

Link to detailed pages for each control group.

docs.title: Compliance
docs.text:
Document applicable standards and how the groundstation aligns with them.

  • EuRoC rules, range safety requirements, electrical safety standards.
  • Data handling/privacy requirements if applicable.
  • Evidence mapping: which documents/tests demonstrate compliance.
  • Open items and planned improvements.

docs.title: Emergency Procedures
docs.text:
Clear, short actions for time-critical scenarios.

  • Abort/failsafe activation steps.
  • Fueling/pressurization emergencies.
  • Fire, loss of containment, or personnel injury response.
  • Communication loss and how to revert to manual control.
  • Post-incident actions (log preservation, reporting).

Format as checklists and keep printable versions available at the pad.

docs.title: Failure Modes
docs.text:
Enumerate credible failures and system responses.

  • Link/network loss.
  • Power anomalies (brown-out, over-voltage).
  • Compute failure or reboot mid-operation.
  • Sensor faults and spurious inputs.
  • Button/indicator failures.

Summarize expected states, alarms, and operator actions.

docs.title: Hazard Analysis
docs.text:
Identify hazards, causes, mitigations, and verification.

Hazard Cause Mitigation Verification Residual Risk

Reference related interlocks (interlocks.md) and procedures (emergency-procedures.md).

docs.title: Interlocks
docs.text:
Describe hardware and software interlocks that enforce safe behavior.

  • Physical interlocks (relays, keyed switches, dead-man).
  • Logical interlocks (state checks, multi-party confirmation).
  • Arming logic and inhibit paths.
  • Health monitoring and fail-open vs. fail-closed rationale.

Document test procedures for each interlock path.

docs.title: Safety Philosophy
docs.text:
State the principles that govern all safety decisions.

  • Default-to-safe: how the system behaves when uncertain or degraded.
  • Human-in-the-loop: when human confirmation is required and why.
  • Independence: separation of command, telemetry, and safety circuits.
  • Evidence: how safety claims are verified (tests, inspections, analysis).

Use this section to align reviewers on intent before diving into details.

docs.title: Software Architecture
docs.text:
Summarize the software system that runs on the groundstation.

  • Major services and their responsibilities.
  • Data flows between services and external systems.
  • Process supervision model (systemd, containers, etc.).
  • Separation of safety-critical vs. non-critical processes.
  • Reference diagrams in telemetry-pipeline.md and dashboard.md.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Describe how configuration is stored, applied, and versioned.

  • File locations, formats, and default values.
  • Secrets handling (credentials, tokens) and rotation plan.
  • Environment-specific overrides (lab, field, competition).
  • Configuration change process and rollback steps.

Document how operators confirm the active configuration before operations.

docs.title: Dashboard
docs.text:
Document the operator UI (if software-based) and its relationship to the physical UI.

  • Data sources and update rates.
  • Critical widgets (arming state, pressures, temperatures, valve status).
  • Alerting thresholds and acknowledgement flow.
  • Offline/low-bandwidth behavior.
  • Authentication/authorization if applicable.

docs.title: Operating System
docs.text:
Document the base OS configuration.

  • Distribution/version, kernel, and real-time settings (if any).
  • User accounts, roles, and authentication methods.
  • Hardening measures (firewall rules, secure boot, auto-updates policy).
  • Time sync strategy.
  • Disk layout, logging, and rotation policy.

docs.title: Services
docs.text:
List and describe services running on the groundstation.

Service Purpose Startup Dependencies Notes

Include health monitoring, watchdogs, and restart policies.

docs.title: Telemetry Pipeline
docs.text:
Explain how telemetry is ingested, validated, stored, and forwarded.

  • Protocols used (vehicle → GS, GS → dashboard/logging).
  • Message schemas and validation rules.
  • Buffering, rate limits, and back-pressure behavior.
  • Data retention and export paths.
  • Synchronization with dashboard and alerts.

Add a sequence diagram here or link to diagrams/system-block-diagram.md.

docs.title: Update Strategy
docs.text:
How the groundstation software is updated without breaking operations.

  • Update channels (stable/testing) and versioning scheme.
  • Deployment method (packages, containers, Ansible, manual scripts).
  • Pre-flight checks and post-update validation.
  • Rollback mechanisms and how to verify integrity.
  • Maintenance windows and who approves updates.

docs.title: Acceptance Tests
docs.text:
Final validation before field use or competition.

  • Test matrix tied to top-level requirements.
  • Dry-run operational rehearsal with full checklist.
  • Safety sign-off steps and authority.
  • Data packages to keep (logs, test reports, photos).

Record results and deviations for each build or revision.

docs.title: Hardware Tests
docs.text:
Tests for boards, harnesses, and power.

  • Power-on self tests and expected measurements.
  • Load/soak tests for power rails.
  • Continuity checks and polarity checks for connectors.
  • Environmental tests (vibration/temperature) if applicable.
  • Acceptance criteria and recording template.

docs.title: Software Tests
docs.text:
Tests for services and data flows.

  • Unit tests, integration tests, and system tests.
  • Simulation of telemetry/command paths with expected responses.
  • Fault injection (network loss, sensor faults) and expected safe behavior.
  • Performance tests (latency, throughput).

Document test automation and manual steps separately.

docs.title: Test Strategy
docs.text:
Define how the groundstation is verified from unit level to acceptance.

  • Objectives: demonstrate safety, reliability, and performance.
  • Levels: unit, integration, hardware-in-the-loop, field.
  • Environments: lab vs. pad vs. dry-runs with simulated vehicle.
  • Entry/exit criteria and documentation requirements.

Link specific tests to requirements for traceability.
